title: Human Ken Doll Rodrigo Alves SLAMS new Channel 4 plastic surgery show
text:
The man known as the Human Ken Doll has spoken out against a new reality show that offers contestants the chance to win their dream plastic surgery.

Rodrigo Alves, 36, from Brazil, branded Channel 4's The Surjery 'tasteless' - despite transforming his own appearance with 72 procedures costing £600,000.

Speaking to Metro.co.uk, he voiced concerns that those taking part in the show, which is set to be hosted by Caroline Flack, may feel pressure to go through with cosmetic procedures that they could later regret or could lead to complications.

Rodrigo Alves, 36, from Brazil, pictured, branded Channel 4's The Surjery 'tasteless' - despite transforming his own appearance with 72 procedures costing £600,000

Rodrigo said: 'It sounds like a very bad idea because having body modifications and plastic surgery is a very personal thing and one must never be under influence of others judgment and opinion.

'I find it tasteless and it puts pressure on people to maybe have a unwanted procedure and regret it, and come back for more which can lead to complications.'

The 36-year-old has experienced a number of complications with his own cosmetic procedures, including struggling to breathe through his nose.

Rodrigo has also had a Brazilian Butt Lift, liposuction and the removal of his fake six-pack is currently preparing to undergo surgery on his chin.

The Surjery will see contestants try and convince a 12-strong jury that they should be given their dream plastic surgery procedure. Channel 4 has not yet confirmed an air date.

Rodrigo (pictured) has experienced a number of complications with his own cosmetic procedures, including struggling to breathe through his nose.

Speaking around the time that the concept was announced, Channel 4 director Ian Katz, claimed their aim is to 'make entertaining, mischievous and innovative shows about the big issues and arguments in Britain today.'

However a number of people have spoken publicly against the format.

One doctor who was due to take part in the show claimed he turned down the offer because it seemed unethical.

Meanwhile Flack became embroiled in a Twitter spat with fellow TV star Jameela Jamil after announcing her participation.

Jameela compared the show to sci-fi drama Black Mirror as she argued that it preys on people's insecurities.

Caroline Flack (pictured) is due to present the Channel 4 show. She was forced to defend herself after she was attacked on Twitter by Jameela Jamil

Caroline responded: 'As you know self image is a complicated, sensitive and personal subject.

'At the heart of this show are people not contestants who have sought help to want to better them selves in their own eyes. Their stories deserve to be told and not ridiculed online.'

A Channel 4 spokesperson told Mail Online: 'Cosmetic surgery has become an increasingly mainstream choice in Britain. The Surjury seeks to explore why so many people feel the need to change their bodies, and whether surgery actually makes them happier.

'All contributors featured in the series have actively been seeking surgery of their own accord. This new series allows them to consult with surgical teams and then to discuss their reasons for wanting it with a panel of their peers. If their peers support their decision they will undergo the procedure of their choice subject to the usual surgical checks and consent processes.

'The show will neither glamorise nor condemn their choices: the aim is instead to interrogate the realities of cosmetic surgery.

'Duty of care to contributors is of paramount importance and all will be independently assessed by the clinic who will carry out their procedure. They will be psychologically assessed and supported regarding their involvement in the programme.'
description: Rodrigo Alves from Brazil, who is best known as the Human Ken Doll, has slammed Channel 4's The Surjery. The show sees contestants try to convince a jury to approve their cosmetic procedures.
